name: Dawn of Industry
description:
Use that Bronze and Iron to craft better tools. Build a basic steam powered machine factory! 
 Steel will come. And with it come many oportunities for industrial upgrading.

quests.name: Steam Age
quests.description:
True machine power at this era comes in the form of Steam. A gas that has to be produced by heating water, and then piped to a consumer. Railcraft also has steam boilers, and can generate RF directly from steam, and they neither explode nor melt; Alas, the RC boilers only come in Iron and Steel, require blaze powder to make Fire Charges for their self-ignition feature, only run on common fresh Water, produce decimal amounts of Steam per tick, and don't auto-emit. 

 Like a crucible, the boiler can overheat and melt, and like a pipe it can also become overfilled and explode from pressure. At least it has a built-in pressure gauge. 
 Note that GTPipe physics can occasionally get confused when merging flows of different sizes, try to balance the inputs to any segment; a pipe intersection will balance its own outputs.

tasks.longDescription: The power from fuel - solid, liquid, or gas - is almost always created as heat (HU) in GregTech. These are combustion engines after all; air will also be required, and either ashes or CO_2 waste products will generally be produced.

This 4B tank only holds types of water. Be aware that it will calcify and lose power capacity unless pure Distilled Water is used. Use a Magnifying Lens to check how bad it gets. Also, like the drums, it cannot accept water direct from buckets - use a Tiny Funnel attachment to fill by hand. 
 Naturally, it takes some time and energy for the cold boiler to heat up to operational temperature. It is thus preferable for steam power to be running for as long as possible per cycle.

quests.name: Turbine be Mine
quests.description:
This device consumes steam to produce RU, rotary power - not to be confused with RoC Shaft Power. This is used by GT machines that need to spin in any way. As a by-product, if a tank or pipe is on any of the sides of this device, it will return most of the water content of the steam (by GT standards) as pure Distilled water. 

 Naturally, if it gets provided steam over the limit (twice nominal flow), it will make a god-awful racket for a second or two and then violently explode. Prehaps selecting the steam input pipe to transfer less than the limit per tick is wise (exploding pipes are relatively cheap, and one can make a pipe release valve).

tasks.longDescription:
All GT devices are strongly sided. Steam comes in the back, RU comes out the front, and distilled water could come from any or all of the other four faces. Connect the RU consuming machine, and various pipes, with that in mind. Unlike processing machines (or burning boxes), power providers like this can actually be rotated to face up or down in addition to the horizontal sides. 
 As is logical, right-clicking with the wrench on a pipe will toggle the connection on this face or edge-adjacent face, shift-right-clicking toggles the opposite face's connection - which can also be done by right-clicking on any corner.

quests.name: Pounding Power
quests.description:
The reciprocating piston Engines provide alternating KU, kinetic power, used by GT machines that need to shake or press. A Screwdriver (or Selector Cover) can be used to cycle them to faster or slower beat cycles - which can be very important to some consumers and some recipes. in general, shorter term recipes want faster engines than the long term recipes. 

 They also emit RF natively, if a compatible device is placed on the output.

tasks.longDescription: Wheter steam or flux, these will shake, pound, and rachet away at any task set before them.

quests.name: Drain Pipe
quests.description:
The Drain cover takes any fluid that would try to flow through its face, were the pipe removed, and puts it into the pipe. This can be used to drain lava, oil, fresh water, or etherium pools. It can also collect rain if pointed up into an exposed sky while it is raining (not snowing). 

 Most importantly, in a River Biome it collects fresh Water without removing the source block (but only inside the River Biome, not the visible feature). Similarly, Riverwater will provide infinite fresh Water, and Seawater provides infinite briney SeaWater. 
 A drain never overfills the pipe, and can only pick up one block of liquid at a time.

tasks.longDescription: The Drain is a type of Cover, it goes on the side of an existing Pipe block. You can slide them in on the edge adjacent side, or place directly on the visible face.

quests.name: Nicely Flattened
quests.description: For now, a Rolling Mill is more useful than a Compressor. Either can make the Dense Plates needed to improve the steam boilers and burning boxes. The Rolling Mill however, can also turn any ingot or stacked ingot into a plate losslessly, and it also flattens curved plates. While the Compressor could use plates or triple plates in addition to Solid Blocks or Blocks of Plates of metal to make a dense plate, it can also make Crystalline Plates from most gem-material dusts (of available tier - and since that means not Diamond, we probably don't care yet).

tasks.longDescription: These will be needed to upgrade your steam production facilities.

quests.name: Down the Sluice!
quests.description: The Sluice machine performs the simple stir in water ore processing step far better than tossing it in a cauldron ever will. Some purified ores can even be further refined in the centrifuge. Even the copious amounts of Sluice Juice byproduct can have useful materials extracted from it, with the right machines.

tasks.longDescription: Now you can retire that cauldron. But, washing ore is a 32RU/t job that takes plenty of clean Water (not seawater). Thus you will need at least an Invar Turbine to run this consistently. Your choose whether to store or void the sluice juice until getting the overclocked centrifuge running. Check out some multiblock tank options.

For now, you probably only have materials for the tier 1 Bronze Centrifuge. And unless you have Bees or Bumblebees, there are very few easy centrifuge recipes to care about. It does a lot of de-alloying, for materials of the machine's tier, and can refine a select few washed ores. But the major reason everyone should get a centrifuge already is the processing of Sluice Juice - which is a 64RU/t recipe (and so is the non-optional reason to need one later). And that is exactly its failure limit!

Remember that part about machines blowing up when they exceed their power limits? Well, the centrifuge is part of the ore processing chain only when powered to exactly its limit, and powered at that level continuously: two ticks lower in a minute and the recipe fails. This means the boiler must be producing exactly the right amount of steam (no pipe has 192mB/t bandwidth = flow rate); and that means it must be in perfect condition with ZERO calcification. So only run this Strong Bronze Boiler (192mB/t steam) on pure distilled water that you have collected as condensate from running less fussy machines. Remember to put in EXACTLY 96HU/t, like a Dense Bronze Burning Box. 
 While you're at it, better use a Bronze Axle fuse. The axle will pop off into the world if it gets overpowered, with no loss in material if it gets picked up (perhaps by a hopper, robot, worker ant, golem, magnet obelisk, or whatever).

quests.name: Whet Sand
quests.description: The Sharpening of raw tool head casts is an important step in making tools out of better materials - like obsidian. While this can be done by in hand crafting with a File, using the Grindstone only consumes sand instead of tool durability. Using the Sanding Machine consumes only power, and the contained space even recovers the dust shaved off the cast!

tasks.longDescription: The iron standing grindstone wears down blocks of sandstone to sharpen things, you will have to replace it frequently. The sanding machine takes RU power instead, and is made of sandstone blocks.

Obsidian is the replacement for flint as your basic tool material. It still has Fire Aspect when fighting, has good enough durability, the raw material is plentiful, and it has a higher mining level. Lava can be poured directly into the Crucible to be turned into hot obsidian scrap, where only a little heat is needed to re-melt it for forming in a mold or basin.

quests.name: Efficient Manufacturing
quests.description:
Ease up on the Wire snips, get a Wiremill to pull transmission wire or fine wire thread losslessly! 
 The Cluster Mill is dedicated to making foil, and nothing else, but does so losslessly unlike hammer and anvil rolling.

tasks.longDescription: These machines only need to be run for specific batches of each component, so you would just pick them up when not in use and share a single turbine or axle mount point.

While we're on the topic of lossless production, only the Lathe can make Screws right. Unfortunately this requires a diamond chip for the cutting head. Taking a Saw to some Chipped Diamond Gems gets them well enough.

quests.name: Mechanization
quests.description: Less about preventing waste, more about having new options, but basically about having a machine that can craft a stack (or chest full) of something while you're off doing something more interesting.

tasks.longDescription:
The Roll Bender makes round things neatly: curved plates, springs, even Cans. No more relying on the Hammer and Anvil for them. 

 The Loom can make cloth better than by hand, and braid or spin wire together - now with special features for OpenComputers data cables and AE system cable.
The Squeezer mechanizes Juicing things, it often gets more (even double) the fluid output per item, but often has less solid rind left over than hand juicing. Plus, it has a pipe outlet!

quests.name: Sifting for Loot
quests.description:
If you have picked up some Sand Ore (in a desert) or Gravel Ore in a pocket, you will have noticed they cannot be washed in a Sluice or Cauldron. These ores are "washed" dry by the sifter. 
 Also, Crushed gem-like or crystal-type ores, which includes the coal varieties, can be sifted to retrieve a mixture of Gem items and Dust piles. True crystalline gems come in several varieties / denominations, which can be broken down but some recipes require the larger ones.

tasks.longDescription: There is no difference in output between the hand Sifting table and the Sifter machine, the only choice is automation and steam power versus time and food energy.

quests.name: Chewy
quests.description: The gizzard for your ore processing, the Crusher makes two Crushed Ore per block of Ore put in - double the Hammer harvesting rate.

tasks.longDescription: Alas, the crushing faces of this machine are stock Diamond Gems. But ore doubling is worth two diamonds, right?

quests.name: Early Game RF
quests.description:
There is quite a list of RF generators at the Iron Age (or before), longer than the list of potential consumers until the Steel Age at least. RF lends itself well to storage and re-distribution using a system of batteries and wires that are also much more forgiving than the Electrical Era is going to be. 
 Note that the Fluxic power convertors (Engine, Motor, Heater, Magnet, and Cooler) from GregTech do have maximum input limits before they fail, which happily coincide with the transfer rates of IE wire connectors!

tasks.longDescription:
Pre-Iron engines - Forestry: Peat Engine, Clockwork Engine; BuildCraft: Sterling Engine; Railcraft: Hobbyist's Steam Engine; Gregtech: Engines (KU is auto-converted to RF). 
 Iron Age engines - Railcraft: Commecial Steam Engine; BuildCraft: Combustion Engine. 
 Steel Age engines - Railcraft: Industrial Steam Engine.

The primary RF transmission method in this pack are the IE wire coils, via connectors and relays. Logistics Pipes can be upgraded to do so too, and they have a much higher transfer limit; BC Kinesis Pipes may also be a viable alternative up to MV, which you can already make wires for. 
 Remember, wires do lose energy in transit.

IE is also the provider of the primary Iron Age RF storage block: the LV Capacitor. Knock sides with the Engineer's Hammer to cycle between input, output, and disconnected modes. Once again, upgraded Logistics Pipes could fill this role, but that upgrade takes BC chips from the laser table.

quests.name: Item Transport
quests.description: Hoppers don't move things very fast or very far, going beyond input and output buffer chests on your machines requires actual transport. GT Item Pipes of various materials work well, as do IE Conveyor Belts.

tasks.longDescription: Conveyor Belts not only move items, they also pull entities along, and are components in several IE multiblock machines. Alas, they move items as entity stacks so it is very suceptible to interference and takes render effort.

Simply moving everything is only helpful. Sorting what gets put where allows for multi-stage processes to be automated (there are so many by-products from GT Ores after all). The IE Item Router is often better than GT Filter Covers from the Modern (MV) Era.

quests.name: Logistics
quests.description: Logistics Pipes are outrageously effective at sorting and transporting items. That mod even provides autocrafting blocks and eventually a nice central interface to retrieve things from. All it takes is a steady RF power supply.

tasks.longDescription: Like BC extraction pipes, there is a small passive RF drain for extraction pipes and modules. The real RF cost comes from every intersection routing things, and request pipes asking for things to be fetched.  All that power must come from a Logistics Power Junction block, which can accept RF from the remaining 5 sides.

The super cheap unrouted pipe gets very confused if it is an intersection, make sure Basic Pipe or any specific pipe made from them are used at every potential branch in the path. Yes, they take diamond gems, but the batch size is large (64 per 2 diamonds and 8 gold gears or BC chips). 
 The pipe can always accept items being pushed into it, but will only send it's contents into the one block it is facing - generally the block it was placed against, but it will select a valid inventory side if placed against a wall.

Open the GUI on one Basic Logistics Pipe with a BC-compatible Wrench, and it can be set to DEFAULT to drop all un-routed overflow into the connected inventory. Pre-sorted inventories should use a Logistics Chassis with a Polymorphic ItemSink Module to accept only more copies of what is already inside, while single item mass storages of any kind can get away with a basic ItemSink Module in thier Logistics Chassis. The system input can work on any inventory by using an Extractor Module, likely a mk2 or mk3 for speed, and optionally Advanced Extractor Module for filtering.

Simply choosing destinations for incoming items won't run an ore processing plant, the input batch size is simply too large. Rather, put Provider Pipes or Modules on the raw material (ore) storage, probably as the second slot in their Chassis, and Supplier Pipes or Modules on the machine to keep it full of the selected things. Remember to allow the outputs to be pushed into the system, and have somewhere for them to route to (or enough space in the defualt). 
 Similarly, fluids can be extracted, insterted, default routed, and provided to machines via suppliers - but only with specific Pipes as there are no liquid modules. Therefore, the only benefit over GT (multi-)pipes is routing.

quests.name: Familliar Old Hell
quests.description: Of great import is the Miniature Nether Portal. It follows the same 8 to 1 spatial compression, fuzzy endpoint detection, and iginition trigger as the full-size portal does, opening many useful ways to exploit the territory. It cannot transport entities, rather it acts like a trans-dimensional universal extender, any-Greggy-thing piped or wired in one side will be piped or wired out the other as if the nexus was the same type of pipe or wire. Items, fluids, redstone signals, and power (EU, LU, RU, even RF) all work this way.

tasks.longDescription: I won't mention how to build the portal frame, only that any firestarter will do.

quests.name: Blast that Furnace!
quests.description:
Using nothing more than coke, iron, and time, these machines can make Steel. 
 The RC version can also recycle (poorly) some things made of iron or steel; the early IE version cannot be automated (it doesn't interact with pipes or hoppers), and produces Slag by-product. Not to worry, I've added a recipe to upgrade the RC one into IE's better furnace once you have 27 Plates of Steel.

tasks.longDescription: You could make 27 IE blast bricks in a 3-cube and knock it with a hammer, or you could build 34 RC blast furnace bricks in a hollow 3 cylinder 4m tall.

quests.name: Grand Tanks
quests.description:
No, not the AFV kind. 
 Mass liquid storage is a helpful stopgap for sluice operations, but it will become more important once you start fractionating petrol. Also during the Chemical Age mass gas storage becomes an issue too. 
 Some playstyles will simply end up accumulating large quantities of certain fluids, and want to decorate their land with massive storage structures.

tasks.longDescription:
Only the iron-bound Wooden Tank can be built without Chemical Era metals, but it still holds 16B per block (Unlike the item storages, GT Drums and Tanks do get bigger when made of stronger metals). Be aware that it is made of wood, so it cannot hold gasses, and will burn up if exposed to hot molten liquids. 
 The singular main valve block, placed in the centre of any face, will auto-emit if in a side, and the top or bottom will also depending on whether the fluid is lighter or heavier than air (see tooltips in NEI recipe lookup). Pipes can connect anywhere on the structure to input to, or actively pull from, the tank.

A building made of sheet metal blocks held up by treated wood fences, the fixed size IE tank remains competitive due to fair capacity coupled with custom model aesthetics. The redstone dependent auto-emit feature on the bottom block is also quite nice.

quests.name: the Riddle of Steel
quests.description:
There are many types of steel, and sometimes they are interchangable. Other things require simple, common, carbon steel. 
 Always made from Iron, there are several ways to addmix and modify the material into a steel state. One of them even goes directly to a specific sub-type of steel.

 Steel is much stronger than Iron, allowing more machines to be built from it, and providing somewhat more useful in the construction of tools. It also allows the creation of Weight and Volume Sensors to assist in inventory automation and crucible fuel calculations.

tasks.longDescription:
50 parts Wrought Iron, 1 part pure Carbon. Pure Carbon!? Hopefully some washed off your diamonds, or you found a full vein of graphite (with the diamonds embedded therein), or you'll have to melt down diamonds to get it. 51 parts, but the crucible only holds 16! 
 I guess quarters will do, or two nineths.

quests.name: Engineer Immersively
quests.description:
Much of Immersive Engineering remains using generic steel as its key component. The Fluid Pump is good at picking up oil or lava, and Fluid Pipe is comparable to steel pipes - the Pump is also an infinite source of fresh water (always check water quality first). A Crusher could be helpful for a mob farm, or to get more standard Gems from ores, it is inferior to the default GT ore processing chain otherwise. A Bottler only does automated container filling, yet it is the only machine to do so until the LV Electric Machine Age. Conversely, the Metal Press is obsolete compared to a GT workshop.
 If you have enough lava and steel, the Immersive Integration Industrial Coke Oven can replace an entire bank of common IE and RC coke ovens.

tasks.longDescription:
The upgraded Blast Furnace structure pulls and pushes like a GT machine, and has upgrade ports to use RF in the Modern Era (aka MV Age).
 An Arc Furnace cannot be properly powered yet, but does work slowly and expensively on 3072RF/t from triple MV connections - a price to weigh against the difficulty of alloying operations the GregTech way. Greg already handles recycling and ore processing better than a hobbled arc furnace can, those options need to wait for HV cable.

Another 3-cube, this one is strongly sided. The Autocrafter (IE) structure uses RF to perform three crafting recipes (potentially in order) from its internal inventory, and can output the results. It surpasses other crafting methods for the ability to use internal fluid tanks as proxy for fluid containers in those recipes, without actually needing to have the container be present.

quests.name: Green Diesel
quests.description: Biodiesel production was very important for basic HV IE, but the fuel oil fraction (Gasoline) makes a better fuel for that Electrical Age generator, and other liquid fueled purposes. The main benefit to biodiesel being non-petroleum is the freedom to make as much farmland dedicated to growing the fuel as you feel like, with no other limit to its supply.

tasks.longDescription: The IE squeezer can do a few of the things the GT Squeezer can do, but is the only way to get IE Plant Oil, a very thin version of seed oil, without using the Generifier. It's pair partner, the Fermenter (IE), only makes one thing: "ethanol" (IE), which isn't used anywhere else.
Combining these two fluids produces a viable liquid fuel.

quests.name: Mineral Excavation
quests.description: An iconic element of IE, the big-toothed void miner. These out-of-world mineral deposits will become exhausted eventually, while still providing several times the ore of an in-world mineral vein. One of RF/u0027s forgiving features as implemented here, is the ability to run part time when given insufficient power.

tasks.longDescription: Much like picking up rocks to find ore veins, the Core Sample Drill must be operated in every "chunk" (square chain) of land in case it discovers a void ore vein there. They are fairly rare, but it's still more common than blindly stumbling across an ore flower patch.

It takes 4096 RF to makes this wheel turn, but at least it can wait the other tick while your three MV connectors valiantly try, and fail, to feed it enough power. Just think of the engine array you'll have to build to get even that much RF/t...

quests.name: Buzz Slice
quests.description: At last! The age of sawing wood planks by hand is at an end. It also saws gems (at Tier 2 or above), and many block slabs. Another improvement is recovering the sawdust from cutting plates into eight tiny plates (or sheets).

tasks.longDescription:
This does everything you think an industrial table saw should do, including needing a supply of lubricant - though it can usually make do with water or grease. 
 No, you cannot make a tier 2 one yet.

quests.name: Extrusion
quests.description:
The process of shoving a soft material through a cut gap to control the cross section is the subject of several children's toys. While also useful in the pottery studio, here we can use heat to make some low-temperature metals soft enough to extrude also. 
 While you are cutting the various shapes into plates, pick one to check NEI for the list of metals that can be formed this way (the input list per material is enormous - 20 to 60 each, so book some scrolling time here).

tasks.longDescription: And a diamond-edged saw blade. The tier 1 heat requirement can be met by most any burning box of 64HU/t or less (overwhelmingly 16 HU/t will do), to avoid making the machine parts themselves gooey.

A form that can only be extruded, it has no crafting recipe, the Capsule-Cell-Container is your gas-tight cup. They do have not have the bonus to safety temperature that molds, pipes, and tanks enjoy, and are all a single bucket size, but also only take a single unit of material to make. 
 Gas Cylinders on the other hand can be crafted and hold up to 8 cubes; they can even be placed in world and given a volume limiter. Cap-Cells make for a grand way to move small amounts of fluid between a source machine's Nozzle, a storage Cylinder or Drum, and a consumer machine's Cap Nozzle.

quests.name: Baking on Purpose
quests.description:
There are four other heat-based machines available to build at this point in the progression: the Oven, Dryer, Roasting Oven, and Laminator. 
 An Oven is simply a powered furnace, good for little else than cooking. 
 The Laminator will be responsible for putting the glass on Forestry Electron Tubes, but for now all it does is coat things in wax - preferably wooden things in fire-proof wax. 
 The Dryer extracts Distilled Water from many sources, sometimes the solid by-product is actually enhanced by this. Perhaps you should put one between your boilers and the river (or now optionally ocean) so calcification stops being a problem.

tasks.longDescription: Since you can already make tier 2 versions of these machines from Invar, I won't specify which one to get. The power input tier mechanics are standard across GregTech basic machines, although burning boxes rarely match standard denominations.

The Roasting Oven deserves special mention, as it is a key component in improving sulphurous ore processing. The Air Vent Cover acts like a Drain Cover for gasses, but sucks in infinite amounts of Air if there is no specific block in front (and it is on a dimension with an atmosphere). Driving off the SO_2 this way provides much better yields than simply smelting the ore, but the use of breathable air instead of pure Oxygen gas introduces a loss rate. 
 That sulphurous oxide gas will be very useful soon... Where to store it? While IE Metal Drums may do, Gas Cylinders are ideal, holding up to 8 cubes of any gas (but not liquid) in a portable tank. You would just need a Nozzle to empty the Roaster with, which requires a Chemical Era material.

quests.name: Tier Up
quests.description:
You may have guessed that all those bronze machines were a low-tier (1) version; Steel is the base material for Tier 2 kinetic (KU) and rotation (RU) machines, which require at least 64 U/t to operate, and fail (violently) if given more than 256 U/t. 
 Greg's power tiering system bears explaining here though. Those 64 RU/t overclocked recipes are ALWAYS overclocking recipes! The tier 2 machine can only enhance recipes with a base cost less than both the tier limit and one-quarter of the actual power used. Using the higher tier machine then takes only half as much time, at four times the power, for a total of twice the energy.

tasks.longDescription:
Amoung the machines that can be upgraded, the centrifuge has the most new recipes: the alloy separation class. Nearly anything that can be made in a Mixer or Mixing Bowl, or is the result of shapelessly crafting dusts, or mixed alloys in the crucible, can be reduced to component parts by a centrifuge recipe. Most of these are higher tier than the recipe to make the material mind. Some natural materials, like redstone, glowstone, clay, and sand, can also be decomposed. This is in addition to the wider variety of Purified ores that can be Refined. 
 Getting 256 RU/t constantly to double-quick sluice juice centrifugation will be less of a challenge once your Dryer is operational.
